questions.question: Which of the following tumors is best suited to study the mechanism of multi-stepcarcinogenesis?
Which of the following procarcinogens does not require metabolic activation?
questions.explanation: Cyclophosphamide is a directly-acting carcinogen that does not require metabolic activation.Carcinogens can be direct-acting or indirect-acting based on their activation.Direct-acting carcinogens require no metabolic conversion to become carcinogenic. Most are weakcarcinogens, but some are important because they are cancer chemotherapeutic drugs (e.g.,245alkylating agents). The direct-acting carcinogens include:• Alkylating Agents:• ° -Propiolactone• Dimethyl sulfate• Diepoxybutane• Anticancer drugs (cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, nitrosoureas, and others)•Acylating Agents:• 1-Acetyl-imidazole• Dimethylcarbamyl chlorideIndirect-acting carcinogens (procarcinogens) are chemicals that require metabolic conversion tobecome active carcinogens. The carcinogenic product of metabolism is called an ultimatecarcinogen. The indirect-acting carcinogens include:•••Polycyclic and heterocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons:Benz[a]anthraceneBenzo[a]pyrene• Dibenz[a,h]anthracene• 3-Methylcholanthrene• 7,12-Dimethylbenz[a]anthracene•• Aromatic amines, amides, azo dyes:• 2-Naphthylamine (°-naphthylamine)• Benzidine• 2-Acetylaminofluorene•Dimethylaminoazobenzene (butter yellow)• Natural plant and microbial products:• Aflatoxin B1• Griseofulvin•Cycasin• Safrole• Betel nuts• Others• Nitrosamine and amides•Vinyl chloride, nickel, chromium• Insecticides, fungicides• Polychlorinated biphenyls246

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with a hyperpigmented lesion on his face. He is a farmer byoccupation and works for long hours with sun exposure. He is at increased risk for all of thefollowing except:
questions.explanation: Seborrheic keratosis is not associated with exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sun exposure.UV rays derived from sun exposure are associated with the increased incidence of:•Squamous cell carcinoma• Basal cell carcinoma•Melanoma of the skinActinic keratosis is a precancerous skin condition that can cause squamous cell cancer ifuntreated.

questions.question: Which form of radiation is responsible for cutaneous cancer?236
questions.explanation: UVB (ultraviolet B) causes cutaneous cancers due to the formation of pyrimidine dimers in DNA.When DNA absorbs energy from UVB, there is a covalent crosslinking of pyrimidine bases anddistortion of the DNA helix. This prevents proper pairing of the dimer with bases in the oppositeDNA strand.Normally, these defects are repaired by nucleotide excision repair pathway. Defects in nucleotideexcision repair pathway result in xeroderma pigmentosum.UV portion of the solar spectrum is divided into three wavelength ranges:Note: UVC is the most potent mutagen but is not considered significant as it is filtered out by theozone layer.SpectrumUVAWavelength320-40onmUVB280-32onmUVC200-28onm

questions.question: Individuals with repeated exposure to ionizing radiation are at increased risk of which of thefollowing malignancies?
questions.explanation: Individuals with repeated exposure to ionizing radiation are at increased risk of myeloid leukemia.Carcinogenic radiations include:• Electromagnetic radiation -247•X-rays•• y rays• Particulate radiation -• α particlesparticles• Protons• NeutronsCancers due to ionizing radiation:•Most frequent - myeloid leukemia and thyroid cancer• Intermediate frequency - cancers of breast, lungs, and salivary glands• Relatively resistant cancers - cancers of skin, bone, and gastrointestinal tract

questions.question: Which of the following tumors is not caused by microbes?
questions.explanation: Adenocarcinoma carcinoma of the lung is not associated with microbial etiopathogenesis. It isassociated with smoking and genetic predispositions.

questions.question: Which of the following malignancies is caused by HTLV-1?
questions.explanation: Human T-cell leukemia-lymphoma virus (HTLV-1) causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma(ATLL).HTLV-1 encodes the viral protein Tax, which leads to polyclonal expansion of T cells. It exhibitstropism for CD4+ T cells.Human infection requires transmission of infected T cells through sexual intercourse, bloodproducts or breast feeding. Leukemia develops only in 3-5% of infected individuals, typically aftera long latent period of 40-60 years.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of HPV oncoproteins and target genes are correctly matched?237
questions.explanation: The target genes for viral oncoproteins of human papilloma virus (HPV) are as follows:• E6-p53•E7 - RBThe image given below shows the functions of the E6 and E7 oncoproteins of HPV.248Functions of E6 and E7 oncoproteinsTERTIncreasedtelomereexpressionE6p53p53inhibitionHPVRBE2FRERB-E2Finhibition1. Immortalization2. Increased cell proliferation3. Genomic instabilityOMARROWE7p21p21inhibitionCDK4) Cyclin DIncreased CDK4/cyclin D

questions.question: A 13-year-old child presents to the OPD with fever, pharyngitis, and cervicallymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear showed a predominance of lymphocytes. The heterophileagglutination test is positive. The causative organism of this condition is not implicated inwhich of the following tumors?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Thisvirus is not implicated in follicular lymphoma.Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a member of the herpesvirus family, has been implicated in:•African form of Burkitt lymphoma• B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed• A subset of Hodgkin lymphoma• Nasopharyngeal carcinoma• Gastric carcinoma - most common EBV associated malignancy•T-cell lymphoma and natural killer (NK) cell lymphoma

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Epstein-Barr virus is incorrect?

options.A: EBV infection always results in Burkitt lymphoma
options.B: It uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach and infect B cells
options.C: It is implicated in B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed people
options.D: It is a potent inducer of B-cell growth and transformation

questions.explanation: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection does not always result in Burkitt lymphoma.EBV infection is highly prevalent even in areas where Burkitt lymphoma is not found. Itcommonly causes infectious mononucleosis.EBV uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach to and infect B cells. EBV genometriggers B-cell signaling pathways inducing B-cell growth and transformation.The infection of B cells is latent as there is no viral replication and the cells are notkilled. However, B cells latently infected with EBV express viral proteins that result in the abilityto propagate indefinitely in vitro. In the absence of T-cell immunity, EBV-infected B cells canrapidly grow out as aggressive B-cell tumors.249

questions.question: Which of the following pathogens is implicated in the causation of primary effusionlymphoma and Castleman disease?
questions.explanation: Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) is a gamma-herpesvirus associated with Kaposi sarcoma,multicentric Castleman disease, and primary effusion lymphoma.They are lymphoproliferative diseases that are most commonly observed in immunocompromisedindividuals. The viral genome expresses genes responsible for inhibition of apoptosis, cell cycleentry, and angiogenesis.

questions.question: 238A patient presents with abdominal distension and intermittent fever. Peripheral smearfindings are normal. A tumor is resected and the histopathology image of the resected lymphnode is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing follicular hyperplasia of lymphnodes are suggestive of Castleman disease.Castleman disease (angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia) is a lymphoproliferative disorder thatcan be associated with HHV-8 (multicentric Castleman disease or MCD) or idiopathic (unicentricCastleman disease or UCD)There are 3 major histological subtypes:•Hypervascular (UCD) -• Lollipop appearance - atrophic germinal centers with radially penetrating blood vessels• Onion skin appearance of mantle zone around germinal centers• Plasma cell subtype (UCD or MCD) - hypertrophic germinal centers, increased vascularity.• Mixed variant (MCD) - mix of hypervascular and plasma cell subtype features in the same lymphnodeThe clinical features include:Multiple enlarged lymph nodes• Night sweats• Weight loss• Weakness and fatigue.• HepatosplenomegalyAs this condition is associated with elevated levels of IL-6, the treatment involves IL-6 inhibitorslike siltuximab and tocilizumab.Note: Hodgkin's lymphoma has characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells in the histopathologicalsection of lymph nodes.

questions.question: Which of the following is an EBV oncogene behaving like a constitutively active CD40receptor?
questions.explanation: 250LMP-1 is an EBV oncogene that behaves like a constitutively active CD40 receptor.The CD40 receptor-like activity stimulates B-cell growth. LMP-1 activates the NF-κB and JAK /STAT signaling pathways and promotes B-cell survival. It also prevents apoptosis by activatingBCL2.

questions.question: Helicobacter pylori increases the risk of development of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Helicobacter pylori is implicated in the following conditions:• Peptic ulcer• Gastric adenocarcinoma - preceded by chronic gastritis, gastric atrophy, intestinal metaplasia,and dysplasia• MALT lymphoma of the stomach - through polyclonal B cell proliferationHelicobacter pylori is protective for:• Barrett's esophagus• Adenocarcinoma of esophagus

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common endocrinopathy caused by tumors?
questions.explanation: Cushing syndrome is the most common endocrinopathy caused by tumors.Endocrinopathy refers to ectopic hormone production by non-endocrine tumors. Approximately,50% of the individuals with Cushing syndrome as endocrinopathy have carcinoma of the lung,chiefly the small-cell type.Hypercalcemia is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome. Cancer-associated hypercalcemiaoccurs due to:• Osteolysis induced by cancer - due to primary or secondary involvement of the skeleton bytumor• Production of calcemic humoral substances by extraosseous neoplasms - for example,parathyroid hormone-related protein. Only this mechanism is considered to be paraneoplastic.

questions.question: Patients with which of the following tumors present with pure red cell aplasia as aparaneoplastic manifestation?
questions.explanation: Thymoma often presents with pure red cell aplasia as a paraneoplastic manifestation.Thymomas are unusual neoplasms of thymic epithelial tissue, ranging from small indolent tumorsto aggressive thymic carcinomas.Pure red cell aplasia is a rare cause of anemia, caused by the absence of RBC precursors in thebone marrow. Causes of pure red cell aplasia include:-• Neoplasms thymomas and large granular lymphocytic leukemia251• Drug exposure phenytoin, azathioprine, and isoniazid-• Auto-immune disorders - neutralizing antibodies against erythropoietin• Parvovirus infection• Hereditary Diamond Blackfan syndrome-

questions.question: Which subtype of acute myeloid leukemia presents with disseminated intravascularcoagulation as a paraneoplastic manifestation?
questions.explanation: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) as a paraneoplastic syndrome is most commonlyassociated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) and prostatic adenocarcinoma.Major determinants of coagulopathy in APL are endogenous factors of the malignant leukemiccells and their interaction with host defense mechanisms.Factors that cause coagulopathy include:• Increased expression of procoagulant activity (PCA)• Expression of fibrinolytic and proteolytic properties• Secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines - interleukin-1b (IL-1b) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient presents with loss of weight and appetite. On clinical examination,grade IV clubbing is evident. Imaging shows periosteal new bone formation and synovialeffusion. Which of the following tumors is associated with this condition?240
questions.explanation: The given clinical history is suggestive of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. It is commonlyassociated with bronchiogenic carcinoma.Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is characterised by the following:• Periosteal new bone formation, primarily at the distal ends of long bones, metatarsals,metacarpals, and proximal phalanges• Arthritis of the adjacent joints•Clubbing of the digits

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with generalized tiredness, malaise, muscle weakness, andbone pain. Laboratory investigations reveal serum calcium to be 13 mg/dL. Which of thefollowing is lung cancers is implicated in this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and laboratory investigations are suggestive of hypercalcemia. It isassociated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.Tumors associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia:• Breast carcinoma• Lung carcinoma• Renal cell carcinoma• Ovarian carcinoma252

questions.question: Which of the following paraneoplastic manifestations is likely to occur in a patient with aphosphaturic mesenchymal tumor?
questions.explanation: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor presents with osteomalacia as a paraneoplastic manifestation.Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor is caused due to mutation of the FGF-23 gene.

questions.question: A 48-year-old obese female presents with skin changes in her axilla and neck as shown in theimage. Which of the following tumors is not associated with this condition?241

options.B: Bladder carcinomaUterine carcinomad) ThymomaQuestion 22:A 45-year-old patient presents with headache, vertigo, tinnitus, and visual disturbance. Onfurther evaluation, blood hemoglobin and hematocrit levels are found to be 18 g/dL and 62%respectively. Which of the following tumors does not present with these paraneoplasticmanifestations?a) Melanomab) Renal cell carcinoma

questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of acanthosis nigricans. It is not associated with thymoma.Acanthosis nigricans is a disorder characterized by gray-black patches of thickened,hyperkeratotic skin with a velvety appearance. The causal mechanism is immunologic due tosecretion of epidermal growth factor.Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with:• Gastric carcinoma•••Lung carcinomaGynecological cancers• Breast carcinoma• Bladder carcinoma• Gallbladder and bile-duct carcinoma•Acromegaly and gigantismDermatomyositis• Diabetes•Hashimoto thyroiditis•⚫ Lupus erythematosus•Phenylketonuria• Polycystic ovary syndrome•Systemic sclerosis• Wilson syndrome

questions.question: Which of these paraneoplastic syndromes is associated with small-cell carcinoma lung?
questions.explanation: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) is associated with small cell carcinomaof lung.

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient notices spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearlyarranged nodules in different parts of the body. Which of the following malignancies is notassociated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation: The given clinical presentation is suggestive of migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome)and it is not associated with bladder carcinoma.Trousseau syndrome may be encountered in association with deep-seated cancers, most oftencarcinomas of the pancreas or lung. It is caused by hypercoagulability leading to multiple repeatedvenous thromboembolism.Malignant brain tumors, hematological malignancies, and adenocarcinomas of the pancreas,stomach, ovary, uterus, lungs, and kidneys are at the highest risk of venous thromboembolism(VTE) development.Advanced, metastatic cancer has been shown to be associated with an increased risk of VTEcompared with localized tumors.

questions.question: A 24-year-old patient with paroxysmal hypertension is suspected to have malignantpheochromocytoma. Which of the following tumor markers will help you confirm yourdiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The serum levels of catecholamines are elevated in malignant pheochromocytoma. Extra-adrenallocation is the only criteria for malignancy in pheochromocytoma.Pheochromocytoma is a rare catecholamine-secreting tumor that may precipitate life-threateninghypertension. It is classically associated with three syndromes:• von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome•Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2)• Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)Catecholamines produced by pheochromocytomas are metabolized within chromaffin cells.Norepinephrine is metabolized to normetanephrine, and epinephrine is metabolized tometanephrine. Because this process occurs within the tumor, independent of catecholaminerelease, pheochromocytomas are best diagnosed by the measurement of these metabolites, ratherthan by measurement of the parent catecholamines.254

questions.question: Which of the following are oncofetal antigens?
questions.explanation: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are oncofetal antigens.Alpha-fetoprotein is a valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of thefollowing tumors:• Primary hepatocellular carcinoma• Hepatoblastoma• Non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors.Embryonal carcinoma• Teratomas• Choriocarcinoma• Yolk sac carcinoma• Germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumorsRegenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically inducednecrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels.Carcinoembryonic antigen is normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells. It is useful indetection, assessing recurrence, and prognosis of the following tumors:• Adenocarcinoma of lung• Colorectal carcinomaCEA levels >5 ng/dL are noted in ascites fluid associated with malignancy. Canalicular patternfor polyclonal CEA more sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, metastases in pancreaticadenocarcinoma and not sensitive for metastasis in bile duct adenoma.Elevated levels are also present in the following non-neoplastic conditions:• Cirrhosis•Biliary obstruction• Hepatitis• Inflammatory bowel disease• Smokers●Post-surgical bowel sequestration• Mucocele• Benign cysts may be positive for carcinoembryonic antigen

questions.question: A 42-year-old patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. Which of the following glycoproteins isexpected to be elevated in this patient?243
questions.explanation: The level of cancer antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3) is elevated in patients with breast cancer.255The reference range of serum CA 15-3 is less than 30 U/mL. It is used to monitor response tobreast cancer treatment and disease recurrence.

questions.question: A 51-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker presents with dry persistent cough andprogressive dyspnea. You are suspecting small cell carcinoma of lung. Which of the followingtumor markers is likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of small cell carcinoma of the lung (SCLC) in which levelsof neuron-specific enolase (NSE) are elevated.NSE is also called gamma enolase or enolase 2 (ENO2) and is encoded by ENO2 gene. It is aphosphopyruvate hydratase that is produced by small-cell lung carcinomas, which areneuroendocrine in origin. Their levels have been implicated as a prognostic factor for patientswith small-cell lung cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.explanation: NRG-1 (Neuregulin-1) is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs).GIST are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, the stomach being the mostcommon site. They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT. GIST isseen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has an equal preponderance among males and females.Most patients present with haematemesis, melena, or vague abdominal pain. The most commonindications for surgery include bleeding and obstruction.The GIST may occur in a sporadic form or as part of familial syndromes. In sporadic GIST, themost common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRAmutation (8%). Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or amixed pattern.The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, ofspindle-shaped tumor cells.GIST - HistopathologySpindle cellsEpithelioid cells256Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient GIST is a subset of wild-type GIST seen with Carneytriad or Carney-Stratakis syndrome.Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase(SDH) deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be usedinstead.-During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causesseeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs,adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent.Other options:Option A: KIT (CD117): This is the most well-known marker for GISTs. About 85% of GISTs showmutations in the KIT gene, leading to the expression of the KIT protein on the cell surface. KIT isa receptor tyrosine kinase, and its activation is a key driver in the pathogenesis of GISTs.Option B: SDH (Succinate Dehydrogenase): SDH mutations are associated with a subset of GISTs,particularly those that are KIT and PDGFRA wild-type. Loss of SDH function is characteristic ofthis subgroup, and SDH deficiency can be demonstrated through immunohistochemistry.Option C: PDGFRA (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Alpha): Mutations in the PDGFRAgene account for approximately 5-10% of GISTs. Similar to KIT, PDGFRA is a receptor tyrosinekinase, and mutations in this gene can lead to the development of GISTs.257
